page.title: 13OUGHTONHEAD COMMON,HITCHIN
page.content: The River Oughton meanders along the edge of the common, eventually joining the River Hiz. Trout,from the local trout farm, sticklebacks and tadpoles can be found in the rivers.It is generally clean enough for people to swim in. Birds such as Herons and Kingfishers have been seen and Mallards are plentiful. At one end of the Common is a grove of Beech trees originally planted by William Lucas in 1842. Dutch Elm disease has eliminated many trees approaching the common. Near the Beech Wood grow an abundance of Marsh and grassland flowers. Two farms border the common, one farm using the river for drainage and irrigation.
